potato.name: Potato
potato.description: A starchy underground tuber native to South America, now one of the world’s main food crops. Potatoes come in many varieties and can be boiled, baked, or fried.
potato.benefits: Rich in carbohydrates, potassium, and vitamin C; provides quick energy and supports heart health when cooked healthily.

carrot.name: Carrot
carrot.description: A brightly colored (usually orange) root vegetable with a sweet flavor. Often eaten raw, juiced, or cooked in soups and salads.
carrot.benefits: High in beta-carotene, promoting good eyesight, skin health, and immunity.

beetroot.name: Beetroot
beetroot.description: A round, red-purple root with an earthy taste. Used in salads, juices, and as a natural food color.
beetroot.benefits: Improves blood flow, helps lower blood pressure, and supports liver health.

radish.name: Radish
radish.description: A small, crisp, and slightly spicy root vegetable, commonly eaten raw in salads.
radish.benefits: Aids digestion, has detoxifying properties, and is low in calories but high in vitamins C and B6.

spinach.name: Spinach
spinach.description: A green leafy vegetable that can be eaten raw or cooked. Grows best in cool weather.
spinach.benefits: Excellent source of iron, calcium, and magnesium; supports bone health and boosts energy.

cabbage.name: Cabbage
cabbage.description: A leafy vegetable that forms a dense, round head. Comes in green, red, or Savoy varieties.
cabbage.benefits: Rich in vitamin K and fiber; promotes digestion and supports immunity.

cauliflower.name: Cauliflower
cauliflower.description: A compact white vegetable composed of undeveloped flower buds. Often roasted, steamed, or used as a low-carb rice substitute.
cauliflower.benefits: Packed with antioxidants, vitamin C, and choline, which support brain and heart health.

broccoli.name: Broccoli
broccoli.description: A green flowering vegetable closely related to cauliflower. It has thick stalks and green florets.
broccoli.benefits: Rich in fiber, vitamin K, and antioxidants; supports immune function and prevents inflammation.

tomato.name: Tomato
tomato.description: Technically a fruit, but used as a vegetable in cooking. Red, juicy, and full of flavor.
tomato.benefits: High in lycopene, vitamin C, and potassium; good for heart health.

cucumber.name: Cucumber
cucumber.description: A long, green, water-rich vegetable often eaten raw. Grows on vines in warm climates.
cucumber.benefits: Hydrates the body, supports skin health, and aids detoxification.

eggplant.name: Eggplant (Brinjal)
eggplant.description: A purple, glossy vegetable with a soft interior when cooked. Common in Mediterranean and Asian cuisines.
eggplant.benefits: Rich in fiber, antioxidants, and low in calories; helps lower cholesterol and supports heart health.

capsicum.name: Capsicum (Bell Pepper)
capsicum.description: A colorful, sweet vegetable available in red, green, and yellow varieties.
capsicum.benefits: Loaded with vitamin C and beta-carotene; improves immunity and eye health.

mango.name: Mango
mango.description: A juicy, sweet tropical fruit known as the ‘King of Fruits.’ It has yellow-orange flesh and a large seed.
mango.benefits: Rich in vitamin A and C, supports immunity, improves digestion, and promotes healthy skin.

banana.name: Banana
banana.description: A long, curved fruit with a soft interior and yellow peel. Grows in bunches in tropical climates.
banana.benefits: High in potassium, aids muscle function, provides quick energy, and supports heart health.

pineapple.name: Pineapple
pineapple.description: A tropical fruit with rough, spiky skin and juicy yellow flesh. Known for its tangy-sweet flavor.
pineapple.benefits: Contains bromelain, boosts immunity, and reduces inflammation.

coconut.name: Coconut
coconut.description: A large, round fruit with a hard shell, white flesh, and refreshing water inside.
coconut.benefits: Hydrates the body, provides healthy fats, and supports brain and heart health.

apple.name: Apple
apple.description: A crisp, round fruit that comes in many varieties—sweet, tart, red, green, or yellow.
apple.benefits: High in fiber and antioxidants, supports digestion, and lowers heart disease risk.

pear.name: Pear
pear.description: A sweet, bell-shaped fruit with soft, juicy flesh and a thin peel.
pear.benefits: Rich in fiber, promotes gut health, and helps control blood sugar levels.

cherry.name: Cherry
cherry.description: A small, red fruit with a pit inside and a sweet or tart flavor.
cherry.benefits: Loaded with antioxidants; helps improve sleep and reduce muscle soreness.

strawberry.name: Strawberry
strawberry.description: A bright red fruit with juicy texture and tiny seeds on its surface.
strawberry.benefits: Excellent source of vitamin C, boosts immunity, and promotes healthy skin.

orange.name: Orange
orange.description: A round, juicy fruit with a bright orange peel. Grows on evergreen trees in warm regions.
orange.benefits: High in vitamin C, strengthens immunity, and promotes healthy skin.

lemon.name: Lemon
lemon.description: A yellow citrus fruit with a sour taste. Used for flavoring, juices, and detox drinks.
lemon.benefits: Supports digestion, purifies the body, and enhances iron absorption.

blueberry.name: Blueberry
blueberry.description: A small, round blue fruit with a mildly sweet flavor.
blueberry.benefits: Rich in antioxidants, boosts brain health, and supports heart wellness.

watermelon.name: Watermelon
watermelon.description: A large, green-skinned fruit with sweet, red flesh and high water content.
watermelon.benefits: Hydrates the body, cools in summer, and supports muscle recovery.
